purpose: Use this channel for project documentation questions, issues and requirements. Thanks!
text: <@U112NNFV4|joshhus> set the channel purpose: Use this channel for project documentation questions, issues and requirements. Thanks!

It has been proposed that the documentation for the Hyperledger Project refer to the "deliverable" (code/infrastructure) as the "blockchain fabric" -- other suggestions are welcome. It's somewhat important to decide / agree on this, because GitHub doesn't (appear to) support an entities file where a text string / glossary term could be changed later, in a single place/file entry.
Note doc "Issues" will be opened and posted here, for anyone wanting to help on docs.
e.g. <@U112NNFV4> and <@U11MANG9G> are looking at a .io alternative for this Issue: "Join us!!"  <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/issues/1262>

Hi Alice.  A useful exercise for all parties would be for you to go through the process of installing the development environment on your machine.  You could then isolate any areas you find to be confusing/ambiguous or sparse in terms of documentation.  We also have an "elementary" level chaincode tutorial that will introduce you to the basic functionality of blockchain.  <https://console.ng.bluemix.net/docs/services/blockchain/ibmblockchain_tutorials.html>

<@U1CCY165T>:  shoot your question. Let me see if i can answer those.

<@U17GHSSFR>: Alright I'll try a couple. Some of these I think I know the answers to but it's always good to get confirmation. 

1) Is the fabric only being developed "for business"? In other words, will this specific blockchain fabric be usable for the public at large? Say, someone who wants to buy something from Amazon. Or is it possible that Amazon will/could use a fabric like this as part of their transaction protocols.

<@U17GHSSFR>: 2) Is there a specific type of business or a certain type of transaction that's being particularly targeted? Securities trading, for example. Or is the focus more on adaptability to a variety of transaction types? 

The last sentence in #1 was poorly written. What I was trying to say is that even if the average individual customer doesn't really "use" a fabric like this -- at least not knowingly or directly -- it's possible Amazon might use blockchain as part of a transaction that a customer is making. That's what I was trying to ask.

<@U17GHSSFR>: Also important to keep in mind what I'm trying to write is a "big picture" type of document. An introduction from a thousand feet up. But I'd like to be able to integrate what's specific about hyperledger into that if I can. I don't want to waste time saying blockchain can potentially be used to do (certain things) when hyperledger isn't going to try to those things. See what I mean?

Hi Joe, for business, means any transaction, of any type, with value. so literally almost anything. We're emphasizing for business because trusting a distributed authority vs. a single authority is a new concept.
We're proposing this URL for the hyperledger/fabric/docs display: ( <http://hyperledger-fabric.readhthedocs.io|hyperledger-fabric.readhthedocs.io> ) not built yet, just a URL proposal.
We have successfully completed Continuous Documentation for hyperledger/fabric docs with mkdocs and Readthedocs.. Check the  documentation here <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/>

text: I would like to submit a comment to the deployment manual. I am not familiar with a way to propose changes so I will write it here. In <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev-setup/devenv/> the following is written with regards to the host: "Note that your Host should not run within a VM. If you attempt this, the VM within your Host may fail to boot with a message indicating that VT-x is not available.". That may imply that only physical hosts are accepted for this deployment. However, I managed to deploy it on an Ubuntu VM hosted on ESXi 6.0 with hardware virtualization activated through advanced settings ("vhv.enable='true'") which is a common option used to create nested virtualization environment with VMware software.

text: In Consensus FAQ there is a typo or the whole sentence about default consensus implementations has to be rewritten. It says there will be 3 of them whereas the text explicitly mentions only 2 (Noops and PBFT): <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/FAQ/consensus_FAQ/>

I am slightly confused with an answer to FAQ on centrality of Membership Service: In my opinion the simple task of issuing certificates from a single location makes Fabric partially centralistic. If Membership Services cease to function correctly, no certificates are issued and thus, no transactions can be processed and no new members can be enrolled. I would develop this topic further to highlight that there is a possibility to set up highly available or redundant membership services nodes in two geographically separated locations: <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/FAQ/identity_management_FAQ/>

With regards to the performance goal documented here (<http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/FAQ/usage_FAQ/>) I think we are nowhere near this figure. Bluemix website shows 240tx/s ; Digital Assets guys managed to perform 400tx/s with Noops. Do we have a documented evidence that we are nearing 100K tx/s?
the performance goal is a GOAL, nowhere does it claim that the current performance capability is 100k tps
but where are we now from performance perspective vs number of nodes in a PBFT setup?
<@U1P1ZV6RF> as for the first point, yes, that’s a typo. There are only two presently. However, there is active work underway to refactor consensus

Should documents such as this one <https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric> indicate the fabric version, such as Hyperledger Fabric 0.5? ... We are starting to document versions (e.g. 0.6 coming soon), and pointing users to HL repos that don't indicate a Hyperledger Fabric version # will be confusing for new folks.

Ramesh, I think you would just "freeze" and publish a snapshot of the current build as 0.5, and continue all future builds as a 0.6 ... does that sound right Chris ... HL writers might start tagging single-sourced docs content as current or next for the appropriate builds, OR alternatively, there should be multiple, version-specific doc source repos.

In other words, there's planning (and work) involved to fence one version of doc from the next ... and to fence the content differences appropriately / accurately. In this case, maybe we just move forward  (promote 0.5) to the 0.6 version of doc, unless folks would really be using / benefiting from also having the prior and separate 0.5 version of doc.
<@U112NNFV4> actually, no. v0.5 was in July and that ship has sailed. We should publish v0.6 branch and ‘latest'
and when we add new releases, we should publish those as well.

Ramesh can you put a 0.6 label on the current doc build. .... Chris is "Hyperledger Fabric 0.6" the correct notation for a fabric version. ... Not sure how LF handles development for current vs. next builds, but there must be some precedent to follow to keep doc current.

I think HL Fabric is at v0.6 now, and that's a Fabric release right, not a "Project" release. (this is at <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/>) ... Ramesh is adding release version # indicators to the doc, TBA.

text: I am not sure if this was already addressed but it looks like the current documentation in readthedocs does not mention different ready-made deployment topologies encoded into .yml files based in ./bddtests/bdd-docker folder. One may deduce what certain files provide but if a short description of each .yml file would be added, it would definitely help people step straight into a scenario they wish to test their chaincode against. The current documentation promotes single-peer deployment with noops for simplicity but I am pretty sure many people would like to have similarly detailed description of popular deployments (such as chaincode example02) with, let's say, 4-node deployment with pbft and CA.

<@U1P1ZV6RF> we just added a self-contained/standalone deployment for the node SDK, and I am in the process of updating the docs to better call that out from the main readthedocs page. To your point, yes, the example yaml files in the bddtests can indeed be used, but we haven’t really hardened them and we haven’t documented their use. Of course we would welcome help in doing so;-)

as for the point on 4 node deployments and pbft etc I am less sure. Certainly some might want to do that, though most I think just want to get started developing and playing. The consensus implementation is changing significantly enough as to make playing with pbft batch less of a compelling exercise.
We hope to have the new consensus model running shortly in a “solo” mode (one orderer using Kafka) and that we will certainly give some better visibility
finally, I will note that we do have documentation on setting up a network <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Setup/Network-setup/>
granted, it isn’t as compelling as it might be if we pointed to some sample compose files that are known to work

The rationale behind creation of this document is based on my assumption that it may still be interesting to some people working on deployment of Hyperledger Fabric for demonstration in enterprise-like conditions.

Hi everyone, If you are looking for help to navigate Jira and see what the current prioritized list is for fabric at least from my view, please see the <#C0UJTTB5J|requirements> channel. I ask if there is something in your mind that is out of priority order, or simply missing in the near term, please bring it up in the <#C0UJTTB5J|requirements>  slack channel. I’m working to keep the list in order as best I can, but need your feedback as well to help rank these.

I am working on a document that will outline the necessary programmatic changes needed for your Go code in order to function with v0.6.  Additionally, new features and links to pertinent samples and demo repos.

<@U0KM61BCP> : hi! On 2016-09-26 I shared my tutorial on how to deploy Fabric outside of chaincodedev. It was published in <#C111FMZ3M|documentation>. In response, you transformed that static file into a web form (in gerrit I suppose). Now that I have a bit of time I could edit it and have it ready for public use. Unfortunately, Slack does not allow me to scroll back with history and I cannot see a direct link you gave me. If you still have it in your records I would greatly appreciate if you can send it again to me.
added permalinks to fabric documentation in readthedocs. <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/v0.6/>

attachments.fallback:
[October 24th, 2016 6:44 AM] garisingh: <@U2BF87970>  - I'm back.   So hopefully what we can do here is get you up and running with the Docker images and then developing / running your chaincode on your Windows 7 host.

Step 1:    Install Docker Toolbox for Windows  (I think you did this already)

Step 2:    Use the "Docker QuickStart Terminal"  shortcut (either on your desktop or via the start menu) to launch Docker on your Windows host   (if you've done this already, I'd recommend closing any open "QuickStart Terminal" Windows

Step 3:  After launching the "QuickStart Terminal", you'll see a line printed out underneath the Docker picture - something like `...configured to use the default machine with IP <http://XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX|XXX.XXX.XXX.XXX>`    - you will want to capture that IP address as we'll need it when we run the chaincode later

Step 4:  Follow <https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Setup/Chaincode-setup/#option-3-docker-toolbox>  to create a compose file and launch the peer and membership services

text: I'll answer my question: create a JIRA issue.

Hi, I'm having trouble running the chaincode example as specified in the documentation at: <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Setup/Chaincode-setup/> when using the Vagrant setup (option 1) so I was wondering if there are currently any known issues with that setup?

Hi <@U3187PKT2> - what OS are you running?  The vagrant option is really more catered towards people doing fabric development.  It adds complication due to the extra layer of abstraction, and as a result we are re-factoring the documentation to emphasize docker (in the works…)  Try using the docker approach, it’s a much simpler format.  You simply save a docker-compose.yaml file (there are samples further down that page you are on) and then run ```docker-compose up``` from whichever directory you saved it to.  It will spin up a few containers for your peers and for the Certificate Authority.  Then you can register a chaincode with a peer or launch one  as a container.  Let me know if you need help with a Docker approach.

Hello. I hope this is the place to ask about this. I am trying to test the Java chaincode example. I have followed the Docker based approach, not vagrant. I have experience dealing with dockers and use new Docker for Mac. My problems is that in "Java Chaincode Setup" part of the docs explains that I need to use "vagrant", which I didn't install as I want to go directly to the Docker / docker-compose approach. Is there a way to get into Java chaincode development without using vagrant? Also, second question, I see that the example references $GOHOME when talking about gradle. Do I need to use GO lang to deal with Java chaincode programming? Of course any addional docs con Java chaincode will be welcome. Thanks a lot.
I am talking about this guide: <http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Setup/JAVAChaincode/#java-chaincode> thanks

<@U10LM0FFZ> I wanted to try the vagrant option since I'm interested in doing fabric development.
See <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/archives/fabric/p1479563655004067> for the reason why I was running into the problem that I mentioned.

text: Hi I have a question regarding this documentation page: <https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Setup/Chaincode-setup/> I'm running the dev environment in vagrant and trying to deploy chaincode_example01 but it's still requiring me a path parameter while it's mentioned that It's not needed.. What can I do to succesfully deploy the chaincode?

I have setup Hyper ledger v 0.6. 
While executing "Invoke" method of sample application "authorizable_counter", we face issue ... "Failed retrieving extension". 
Did someone face similar issue? if so, please provide us some clue.

Thanks.

<@U3AFRMY68> - do you know which level of fabric code you are running on.  If you have the fabric 0.6 codebase cloned and then you `vagrant ssh` you should be able to compile the chaincode and then deploy to your peer running locally.  Please ensure that you DON'T have the current master branch cloned in your GOPATH.  If you’re still getting stuck please share your logs and I will help you resolve

<@U2T7Z63NY> - can you share some more information.  How did you set up your peers - vagrant or via docker-compose?  If you’re using docker, you should be able to very easily `docker exec` into the container running your peer, then login, then deploy, and then invoke/query.  Please see <https://hub.docker.com/r/ibmblockchain/fabric-peer/> for a simple description on using the v0.6 docker images and corresponding docker-compose scripts

Hi,

Can anyone tell me the use of "TCertAttributesHeaders = asn1.ObjectIdentifier{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9}" in the "<http://github.com|github.com>\hyperledger\fabric\core\crypto\attributes\attributes.go" file.

Thanks
<@U10LM0FFZ> why can't I have the current master branch in the gopath ?

my supposition is that due to the architectural changes and tx flow - endorsement, ordering, validation, commitment that the documentation does not truly reflect the codebase.  (basically the master branch doc is more reflective of v0.6 flow).  Try removing the name `n` argument with `mycc` and instead point to where this go code lives in your GOPATH.  `<http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example01|github.com/hyperledger/fabric/examples/chaincode/go/chaincode_example01>`.  That said, if you do revert your clone to the v0.6 branch, your deploy should work successfully with the `-n -mycc` in your REST call
<@U112NNFV4> - suggest we take this offline.  I can explain

What is the mechanism for ensuring that questions that come into the slacks and mailing lists, once answered, are also documented? The short answer might be a policy to open a JIRA issue for each question/answer, if that's not already being done. Thanks!
there is no formal mechanism. I'd like that we could surface FAQs from the chatter, but to do that effectively really demands crowd sourced effort

note also that there's a recommendation that people post to StackOverflow because that's likely the best platform for crowdsourcing Q&A that ensures (to a great degree) a certain level of consolidation and weeding out obviously unhelpful questions and answers, etc.
Okay, thanks, <@U184J2R7S> asked me about it ... I suppose responders could take it upon themselves to see if it's doc-ed correctly and open a JIRA issue if it isn't.
Please flag <@U112NNFV4> when content on various channels is good for external v1.0 doc. Hard to keep track of all slack channel discussions, thanks!
I need help for installation of hyperledger

<@U3E300R6Z>  I was unclear if you are trying to install Hyperledger-fabric version 0.6 or just working on documentation given the channel you are in.  If you are trying to install the fabric- an easy way to do it is use the docker images on this website: <https://hub.docker.com/u/ibmblockchain/>

If you are not subscribed to the hyperledger fabric channel on youtube already please go out and do so to receive automatic notifications…. Otherwise you might have missed another great video showing how to upgrade chaincode, thank you <@U1VG8LNP3>!! <https://youtu.be/hlJmRKo8HXE>
<@U22RH7VGT> I tried with the dev documentation using below command and deployment worked
Although I had to modify the IPs and names to make it work

I am new to chaincode development. i have previously worked on Ethereum based dapps with contracts coded in solidity
From what I see in examples, there are Getstate and Putstate functions that we can use to write/read key value pairs to Ledger
Now if I need to save complex structured and objects, how can I do that???
Also is there any official API reference containing all chain code functions that I can refer??

We are moving to version 1.0 which is going to allow for more complex structures/objects.  I know there are ways to do this in version 0.6, but you could also look where we are going in 1.0 looking at design specs at this link: <https://wiki.hyperledger.org/community/fabric-design-docs>
most of the chaincode questions are really being posted on fabric-sdk-dev or fabric-dev
Thanks <@U13TWBRBL> New SDK Video posted on youtube, including how build outside of vagrant! <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t7PcpkIoGAc>

text: What are we calling January 31 - is that an IBM delivery, or an LF delivery.

yea that's what I figured.  basically you just push to your fork of the fabric repo on github and then add hooks to build RTD every time you push.
So, RTD/latest is what is currently in master?

yes sir.  It builds against the doc directory anytime there is a new merge.  I will show you how to add the hooks.  Frankly I need a refresher course too.  Yes, you use github to preview the output, and then you can do a real push to gerrit if you like the formatting
